raw_text:
2D Metal Slug offers retro fun
 
 Like some drill sergeant from the past, Metal Slug 3 is a wake-up call to today's gamers molly-coddled with slick visuals and fancy trimmings.
 
 With its hand-animated sprites and 2D side-scrolling, this was even considered retro when released in arcades four years ago. But a more frantic shooter you will not find at the end of your joypad this year. And yes, that includes Halo 2. Simply choose your grunt and wade through five 2D side-scrolling levels of the most hectic video game blasting you will ever encounter. It is also the toughest game you are likely to play, as hordes of enemies and few lives pile the pressure on.
 
 Players must battle soldiers, snowmen, zombies, giant crabs and aliens, not to mention the huge, screen-filling bosses that guard each of the five levels.
 
 The shoot-anything-that-moves gameplay is peppered with moments of old-school genius. Fans of robotic gastropods should note the title refers, instead, to the vast array of vehicles on offer in a game stuffed with bizarre hardware. Tanks, jets and submarines can be commandeered, as well as cannon-toting camels, elephants and ostriches - more weaponry on offer than in an acre of Iraq. Doling out justice is a joy thanks to ultra responsive controls, and while this is a tough nut to crack, it is addictive enough to have you gagging for that one last go. And at a mere £20, Metal Slug 3 is as cheap as sliced, fried spuds, as the man says. Of course, most of you will ignore this, lacking as it does the visual fireworks of modern blasters. But at a time when blockbuster titles offer only a fresh lick of paint in favour of real innovation, Metal Slug 3 is a fresh gasp of air from an era when the Xbox was not even a twinkle in Bill Gates' eye.
llama3.2:1b: Metal Slug 3 is a retro-style shooter with hand-animated sprites and 2D side-scrolling gameplay that offers frantic action. Players must battle various enemies, including soldiers, snowmen, zombies, and bosses in five levels. The game features a unique "shoot-anything-that-moves" gameplay mechanic, addictive controls, and a £20 price tag.
llama3.2:3b: Metal Slug 3 offers retro fun with its hand-animated sprites and 2D side-scrolling gameplay. The game is a frantic shooter with tough enemies, few lives, and ultra-responsive controls. It features a wide variety of vehicles to commandeer, including tanks, jets, submarines, camels, elephants, and ostriches. At £20, the game is affordable, providing an addictive experience despite lacking modern visual effects.
gemma2:2b: Metal Slug 3 is a retro 2D side-scrolling shooter that offers frantic gameplay and tough challenges. The game features hand-animated sprites, diverse weaponry, memorable bosses, and addictive controls. Despite its simplicity, it delivers an authentic shooting experience reminiscent of classic arcade games.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Metal Slug 3 is a retro shooter that offers a mix of nostalgic gameplay and challenging side-scrolling levels. It features hand-animated sprites and 2D side scrolling, though it may not be as experienced or addictive as some other games of the same genre. The game has more complex enemies than in previous titles and includes new vehicles and weapons. Players battle soldiers, snowmen, zombies, giant crabs and aliens on a five-level side-scrolling game.
qwen2.5:1.5b: 2D Metal Slug offers frantic shooting gameplay and retro-style side-scrolling platform elements, challenging players with hordes of enemies and tough bosses while maintaining old-school gaming charm despite modern visuals.
qwen2.5:3b: 2D Metal Slug offers retro fun with hand-animated sprites and side-scrolling gameplay considered retro due to its frantic shooter elements and challenging levels filled with various enemies, including soldiers, zombies, and bosses. The game features a vast array of vehicles like tanks, jets, and camels for players to command. Despite lacking modern visuals, Metal Slug 3 is praised for its old-school genius, responsive controls, addictive gameplay, and affordability at £20. It stands out as a tough but engaging challenge in a market dominated by flashy new titles.

smollm:1.7b:
The summary should be:
2D Metal Slug offers retro fun with hand-animated sprites and 2D side-scrolling, but lacks modern features like graphics and multiplayer. The game is more focused on action than exploration, and the gameplay is repetitive and easy to get wrong.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text about Metal Slug 3 concisely. Let me read through it again carefully.

The first sentence says that Metal Slug 3 is like some drill sergeant from the past, which gives it a retro vibe. It's a game with hand-animated sprites and 2D side-scrolling gameplay. I remember how old-school games are often simple but engaging.

The text mentions that this was even considered retro back in the day, specifically when it was released on arcades four years ago. But now, it seems like Halo 2 is the focus instead of a more frantic shooter because Halo 2 is a video game known for its intense gameplay and tough bossing.

Players get to fight different enemies: soldiers, snowmen, zombies, giant crabs, and aliens, plus there are bosses on each level. The game is described as being as hard as the toughest video game you'll ever play, which makes me think it's challenging but doable if you try your best.

The gameplay has moments of old-school genius; fans might enjoy seeing how robots or other items are used in a game. It's also noted for its responsive controls and addictive nature. The price is low compared to modern games, maybe similar to some "sliced" spicy food.

However, many people might not notice the retro feel because it doesn't compare to the newer, flashy games. But when it comes to gameplay mechanics, it's a fresh take on old-school shooters. I think this game could be great if you want something simple but engaging and challenging.

I need to condense all that into one summary without adding any explanations or formatting. Just plain text with key points about the retro feel, the gameplay elements, the levels, the enemies, the price, the nostalgia factor from Halo 2, and its challenge level.
</think>

Metal Slug 3 offers a nostalgic take on shooters, blending old-school charm with modern action. It features hand-animated sprites, 2D side-scrolling gameplay, and enemies like soldiers, snowmen, zombies, crabs, and aliens, as well as bosses. The game is priced cheaply but can be challenging for those new to the genre. Its retro vibe sets it apart from contemporary games while offering a tough, engaging experience similar to Halo 2's intense gameplay.
tinyllama:1.1b: Metal Slug 3, like its retro-inspired predecessors, offers a visually stunning, fast-paced shooter that requires quick reflexes and strategic planning to clear each of the game's five levels in five 2D side-scrolling sections. In this modern iteration, the titular characters are animated in hand-animated sprite form with 2D side-scrolling segments and a mix of enemies ranging from soldiers to giant robots, birds, and aliens. The gameplay is peppered with moments of old-school genius, including a wealth of vehicle options and the ability to command even the most bizarre weapons such as tank turrets, jet fighters, missile launchers, and elephant tanks. While this may not be the most innovative title out there, Metal Slug 3 is still a fresh gasp of air from an era when gaming was dominated by blockbuster titles that offer only a refresh of paint. The game's low price point makes it a must-buy for fans of arcade shooters looking for a nostalgic thrill.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In Metal Slug 3, players take control of a group of soldiers and have to eliminate enemies, vehicles, and bosses as they progress through the game. The game offers varied weaponry, such as tanks, jets, submarines, and camels, which can be customized and equipped with various weapons. The controls are ultra responsive, making it easy for players to shoot with ease. The game is set in a 2D side-scrolling environment with hand-animated sprites, providing an entertaining and challenging experience. The game offers five levels and features a variety of enemies and obstacles throughout each level, making it a classic shooter with plenty of replay value. Metal Slug 3 is a tough game but also addictive, with ultra responsive controls that make it easy for players to get in and out of action quickly. It offers an affordable price of £20 and is recommended for fans of retro gaming.
phi:2.7b: The text is about a retro shooter game called Metal Slug 3 that offers intense gameplay with unique and bizarre vehicles. It can be addictive despite its old-school nature and is available for £20, making it affordable. The author suggests ignoring this game due to its lack of visual fireworks but acknowledges it as a refreshing alternative to today's blockbuster titles.
orca-mini:3b: The text describes Metal Slug 3 as a retro game that offers intense and challenging gameplay, with hand-animated sprites and 2D side-scrolling levels. It is tough and requires players to battle various enemies and bosses using a variety of vehicles. Despite its difficulty, it is addictive and offers a great value for money at just £20. The text also praises the game's responsive controls and mentions the variety of weapons available, including robotic gastropods. Overall, Metal Slug 3 is an exciting and challenging game that is well worth playing if you enjoy retro games with intense gameplay.
hermes3:3b: Metal Slug 3: 2D side-scrolling shooter with retro visuals, frantic gameplay, tough challenges, diverse vehicles and weapons.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: 2D Metal Slug is a retro game with hectic gameplay and old-school features. It offers a challenging experience with various enemies and boss fights across five side-scrolling levels. The game has a wide variety of vehicles, including tanks, jets, submarines, camels, elephants, and ostriches. With ultra responsive controls and cheap price at £20, Metal Slug 3 is an addictive and nostalgic game that stands out in today's market as a fresh take on the past.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Metal Slug 3 delivers intense, old-school 2D side-scrolling action with hand-animated sprites and relentless gameplay. Despite its retro style, it offers one of the most frantic shooting experiences, challenging players with hordes of enemies, massive bosses, and limited lives. The game features a variety of vehicles, including tanks, jets, and even armed animals, adding to its chaotic fun. With ultra-responsive controls and addictive difficulty, it remains engaging despite lacking modern visuals. At just £20, it provides a refreshing alternative to today's graphically polished but often uninspired games.
stablelm2:1.6b:
2D Metal Slug 3 offers retro fun with its hand-animated sprites and 2D side-scrolling gameplay. Packed with bizarre hardware like vehicles, tanks, jets, submarines, and more, this hectic shooter has the most hectic video game experience compared to Halo ..
  
The text describes Metal Slug 3 as a challenging game filled with enemies like soldiers, snowmen, zombies, giant crabs, aliens, and bosses guarding each of the five levels. The gameplay is shoot-anything-that-moves, peppered with moments of old-school genius. It has ultra-responsive controls that make playing addictive.

The text also highlights its affordability: Metal Slug 3 costs only £10, making it as cheap as sliced potatoes. However, those without the visual fireworks of modern blasters might not appreciate this game's vintage appeal. Despite lacking some aspects of modern games, such as slick visuals and fancy trimmings, the game successfully offers retro fun for gamers seeking an old-school gaming experience.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Metal Slug 3 is a 2D side-scrolling shooter with retro charm, offering intense gameplay compared to modern titles like Halo 2. Players control various grunts, battling diverse enemies and formidable bosses across five levels. The game features an array of unusual vehicles for commandeering, including tanks, jets, submarines, and oddball creatures. Despite its lack of visual spectacle, Metal Slug 3 delivers responsive controls and addictive difficulty, making it a cheap yet satisfying experience at £20. It stands out for being a breath of fresh air from the gaming era before the Xbox's inception.
